0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Cisplatin nephropathy; Prophylaxis: 9 g/m(2) IV push, then 1.2 g/m(2)/hr continuous infusion for 6hrs
  • Cyanide poisoning: 12.5 g IV over 10 min (after sodium nitrite 300 mg); repeat, if necessary, with half doses of both

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Cyanide poisoning: 412.5 mg/kg of body weight or 7 g/m(2) administered at a rate of 0.625 to 1.25 g/min IV

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Cisplatin nephropathy; Prophylaxis
  • Cyanide poisoning
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Antineoplastic adverse reaction - Injection site extravasation
  • Calciphylaxis
  • Carboplatin adverse reaction - Ototoxicity

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:

  • Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: reduced symptoms of cyanide poisoning; for 24 to 48 hours after therapy

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
SODIUM THIOSULFATE
OVERDOSE: Sodium thiosulfate is an agent with a low order of toxicity. It may be a mild irritant in the solid form. Dust and concentrated solutions can irritate the skin, eyes and mucous membranes. Allergic dermatitis has also been reported. Ingestion of large amounts may cause gastrointestinal irritation, nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramping and diarrhea. Hypotension is only predicted following rapid intravenous infusion of very large doses and should be self-limited and transient.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
SODIUM THIOSULFATE
  • Decontamination: ORAL: Activated charcoal.
  • Hypotensive episode: IV 0.9% NaCl, dopamine or norepinephrine. Hypotension is predicted to only follow rapid intravenous infusion of very large doses and should be self-limited and transient.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor vital signs, ECG, acid-base and fluid/electrolyte status as indicated.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
SODIUM THIOSULFATE
TOXICITY: Ingestion of 12 g of sodium thiosulfate was virtually non-toxic except for producing violent catharsis. The lowest toxic intravenous doses for humans were 0.2 to 1.5 g/kg. As much as 9.9 g/m(2) has been given IV with no apparent ill effects. THERAPEUTIC: Adults - Cisplatin nephropathy: 9 g/m(2) IV push, then 1.2 g/m(2)/hr continuous infusion for 6 hrs; Cyanide poisoning: 12.5 g IV over 10 minutes (after sodium nitrite 300 mg); repeat, if necessary, with half doses of both. Children - Cyanide poisoning: 412.5 mg/kg of body weight or 7 g/m(2) administered at a rate of 0.625 to 1.25 g/minutes IV.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause contact dermatitis or diarrhea.
  • Patient should report signs/symptoms of extravasation.
